Biff, Chip & Kipper book ‘The Blue Eye’ withdrawn after Islamaphobia complaints. Published in 2001 (year of 9/11) it features people wearing turbans & niqabs in a market, described as “not very friendly” & the place “scary.”

No longer appropriate? This was never appropriate. 1/ https://t.co/fr1xPLS0Yj

📚Mon:sitting as coroner;taking on Jimmy Lai’s case
📚Tues:settled case for victim of abuse;drafting case on misogyny in Met 
📚Wed:evidence to JCHR on HRA
📚Thurs:filing urgent UN appeal against Iran for BBC Persian 1/2

@jenscotney @BarristerSecret @jessphillips @mattt_morgan Jen,I’m so sorry to hear this. These are such incredibly difficult cases. @BarristerSecret @jessphillips @mattt_morgan This was also a feature at IICSA, for witnesses & core participants primarily (no jury there). “At all levels, white male barristers earned the highest fee income, with black women earning the least.”

@sophisabella Thanks, Sophie. I thought you would! I think it’s partly to do w human rights work being devalued. Everyone feels they can ‘have a go’ in a way that I just don’t think they would try with some other areas of law (or in some areas,they can’t without meeting specific requirements).
@borrettR Phew - and well done!
@borrettR Richard, I am so sorry to hear this. Awful. Hopefully it was fixable, at least? But awful for the client, and a real pain for you and your team.

@SorayaBauwens Absolutely. A repeat problem I see in amateur human rights lawyering is the filing of a complaint with one body - which then prevents the client having access to a much better mechanism/remedy. Needless to say the clients are not properly advised of their options & ramifications.
👏💯 https://t.co/OdLvC0mKZ2

@aliromah Also - bravo to law firms which do paperwork/ bundles, directing their resources to very good use. And to all those who provide invaluable research support to specialist lawyers with tight budgets/ lack of resources. There are many ways to give support well,without doing damage…

@aliromah Exactly this! It may not be as “glamorous” as some people perceive certain human rights work to be, but lawyers giving expert pro bono advice on things like leases is worth far more than high profile work on, eg, a death penalty case in which the lawyers have zero expertise…
@niallfitz This was my favourite of the replies, Niall. https://t.co/QfjBMalzAQ

Sadly I’m working on two cases in which well-meaning pro bono ‘support’ has caused fundamental problems. It’s not acceptable. This is a highly specialist area, in which the stakes for people could not be higher, not a hobby to make people feel better about themselves.

I wouldn’t dream of saying yes to a brief in a highly specialised area of eg commercial litigation in which I’ve no expertise. Indeed it would breach my professional obligations. Why on earth do lawyers w/out expertise in human rights take on cases they are not equipped to do?

PLEASE can people stop conflating pro bono work with human rights work? They’re not the same thing,& treating them as such often means people wading into specialist human rights issues without expertise & making a mess for their clients,but feeling they’re doing good. No. No. No.

7/

HMP Bronzefield & the MoJ have much to answer for here. But there’s also the fundamental question about why this young woman, heavily pregnant, was in prison in the first place, held by the State in a prison incapable of meeting the needs of her & her baby. 6/

PPO: “all pregnancies in prison should be treated as high risk by virtue of the fact that the woman is locked behind a door... In addition, likely to be a higher percentage of ‘avoidant’ mothers who have experienced trauma & are fearful of engaging with maternity care.” 5/

Today’s PPO report makes grim reading, but sadly much of it is v.familiar to those of us who have acted for pregnant women in custody, or babies born to women in custody. These are systemic, long-standing failures: poor info sharing, no coordination, inadequate maternity care. 4/ https://t.co/4foWIHkpAF

*She bit through her own umbilical cord.* You read that correctly. She tried to mop up the blood. She put the placenta in the bin. And she got back into bed with her baby, who was purple & not breathing. Still no one came. She was discovered at 8am. 3/

Parts of today’s report are absolutely horrific. This was a young, scared woman, aged 18, in prison for the first time - in the care of the State. She asked for a nurse, twice. No one came. She gave birth alone, in her locked cell, & passed out from the pain. 2/

2 years since a young woman gave birth in HMP Bronzefield & her baby died. The Prison & Probation Ombudsman has released a damning report today.

‘Ms A’ called for help repeatedly & was ignored. After delivering her own baby,she bit through the umbilical cord & wiped up blood. 1/

@CounselTweets Ha! Not surprised. The terminology has become like terms of art,so it’s used all the time & ordinary words like ‘holiday’ are not shorthand people get in the same way. But this is a reminder for me of avoiding some of the social work/legal shorthand, given its impact. Will try...

And it’s not the same thing, but that ‘respite’ tweet has also reminded me of the ‘Labelled’ exhibition @FoundlingMuseum. Incredibly powerful work by care leavers & artist Emma Middleton, on language used about children in care & how damaging it can be. https://t.co/uga4cqoPZi 3/

There was an excellent piece by Matt Lewis in @CommunityCare a few years ago on how the jargon of care unfairly labels children, & professionals’ complicity in this. Children don’t live in homes, but ‘placements.’ They have ‘carers,’ nor family. https://t.co/ojiDl5sB0d 2/

Oof. The language used about children & young people in need/ in care is so problematic. This is a reminder of how insensitive some terms, now used unthinkingly, are. ‘LAC’ / ‘LAC review’ is another: dehumanising, & sometimes children hear it as if something is “lacking”. 1/ https://t.co/KFrkgnYTYi

#DaphneCaruanaGalizia’s words on abortion tourism & hypocrisy, from an 11 year old blog post, will resonate with many who campaigned to #RepealThe8th or for #TheNorthIsNext. And they remain true in Malta now. Daphne’s blog is here, for those interested https://t.co/yXHwfDdunE 3/3

“The main purpose of Malta’s ban on abortion is now purely symbolic: ‘this is what we stand for’. But there is a secondary purpose: to stop poor people & women financially dependent on uncooperative third parties from having one,” she wrote in May 2010, 11 years ago. 2/

Reminded by @notesfromdaphne @mcaruanagalizia of Daphne’s powerful words: 

“If people can’t get something here in Malta, then they will go outside Malta and get it there... But they must have the money. In 1984, it was toothpaste, pasta and abortion. Now it’s just abortion.”

1/ https://t.co/aVkWpzN10L
